channel.title: NYT > Science
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Jane Goodall Is Self-Isolating, Too
item.description: She’s in England, in the house she grew up in, and she has a few thoughts about chimpanzees, the coronavirus pandemic and the loo paper shortage.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman
item.media:description: British primatologist Jane Goodall in the science museum CosmoCaixa of Barcelona in 2018.

item.title: Life on the Planet Mercury? ‘It’s Not Completely Nuts’
item.description: A new explanation for the rocky world’s jumbled landscape opens a possibility that it could have had ingredients for habitability.
item.dc:creator: Shannon Hall
item.media:credit: NASA/Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory/Carnegie Institution of Washington
item.media:description: The study theorizes that the “chaotic terrain” on Mercury’s surface was formed by activity underneath the planet’s barren, scorched exterior, and not a collision.

item.title: Chimp Sanctuaries Restrict Visits Over Concerns About the Coronavirus
item.description: There’s a possibility chimpanzees could be susceptible to Covid-19, so sanctuaries are taking precautions.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman
item.media:credit: Melissa Golden for The New York Times
item.media:description: A new chimp arrival at Project Chimps, in Morganton, Ga., from the New Iberia Research Center at the University of Louisiana in 2017.

item.title: Turning Back the Clock on Aging Cells
item.description: Researchers report that they can rejuvenate human cells by reprogramming them to a youthful state.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Wade
item.media:description: A scanning electron micrograph of a human embryonic stem cell.

item.title: Welcome to the Virosphere
item.description: SARS-CoV-2, the cause of the pandemic, belongs to one of 6,828 named species of virus. Hundreds of thousands more species are known, with perhaps trillions waiting to be found.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer

item.title: Remember When Japan Blasted an Asteroid? Here’s What We Learned
item.description: The Hayabusa2 spacecraft’s explosive encounter reveals that a space rock called Ryugu looks extremely young for its age.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: The shadow of the Hayabusa2 spacecraft after its successful touchdown on the asteroid Ryugu.

item.title: When Coronavirus Closes Your Lab, Can Science Go On?
item.description: Plenty of work can be done from home, but the pandemic is forcing some parts of the scientific process to be put on the shelf.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Bioluminescent plankton studied in the lab of David Gruber, a biologist at City University of New York.

item.title: The Search for E.T. Goes on Hold, for Now
item.description: A popular screen saver takes a break while its inventors try to digest data that may yet be hiding news of extraterrestrials.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:description: The seti@home screen saver, launched in May 1999, crunched data while your computer was idle.

item.title: Geese May Not Inspire You, but They Certainly Take Your Mind Off the Virus
item.description: Watching birds that do not practice social distancing is a nice break from washing your hands and disinfecting friends.
item.dc:creator: James Gorman and Natalie Keyssar
item.media:description: Gulls, ducks and brants, a type of goose, in Flushing Meadows Park in Queens.

item.title: coronavirus
item.description: The measure promises a $1,200 payout to millions of Americans and increased jobless aid. It also creates a government bailout fund for distressed businesses.

item.title: Standing Rock Sioux Tribe Wins a Victory in Dakota Access Pipeline Case
item.description: A federal judge on Wednesday struck down permits for the pipeline and ordered a new environmental review of the project.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Demonstrators protested against the Dakota Access Pipeline on the National Mall in Washington in 2017.

item.title: Can You Become Immune to the Coronavirus?
item.description: It’s likely you can, at least for some period of time. That is opening new opportunities for testing and treatment.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: A recovered coronavirus patient donated plasma at the Hainan Blood Center in Haikou, China, in February.

item.title: Coronavirus Symptoms Full List: What Are They? Is There a Cure?
item.description: Here’s what to do if you feel sick and are worried it may be the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Experts have urged people not to panic over the coronavirus. “The mantra is, ‘Keep calm and carry on,’” said Dr. Marguerite Neill, an infectious disease expert at Brown University.

item.title: Coronavirus Doesn’t Slow Trump’s Regulatory Rollbacks
item.description: The administration is pushing ahead with efforts to roll back environmental protections and impose new limits on how science can be used for making rules.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: An oil-covered bird in Goleta, Calif., after a spill there in 2015.

item.title: Gilead Withdraws Request for Special Orphan Status on Experimental Coronavirus Treatment
item.description: Critics said the company was profiteering from the coronavirus pandemic by seeking tax and monopoly benefits under a program intended to encourage drug development for rare diseases.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas

item.title: Live Coronavirus Updates and Coverage
item.description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo said there were early signs that New York’s restrictions on gatherings could be slowing the virus but that more needed to be done in New York City.

item.title: Medicare Is Updating Coverage to Help in the Coronavirus Crisis
item.description: With its beneficiaries among the most at risk for Covid-19, the agency is relaxing some rules.
item.dc:creator: Mark Miller
item.category: Centers for Medicare and Medicaid Services
item.media:description: Health care workers handling a coronavirus test at a drive-through station in Stamford, Conn.

item.title: Greta Thunberg Says It’s ‘Extremely Likely’ That She Had Coronavirus
item.description: The Swedish climate activist said she was recovering and urged young people to stay at home, even if they don’t feel sick, to protect those who are more vulnerable.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: Greta Thunberg at a meeting of the European Council in Brussels on March 5.

item.title: Letter of Recommendation: Bog Bodies
item.description: Mummified bodies from the bogs of Northern Europe reveal what the past can and cannot teach us.
item.dc:creator: Robert Rubsam

item.title: Some Doctors Stockpile Trial Coronavirus Drugs for Themselves, States Say
item.description: The stockpiling has become so worrisome that pharmacy boards in many states have issued emergency restrictions on how the drugs can be dispensed.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Gabler
item.media:credit: Ramin Rahimian for The New York Times
item.media:description: A handful of state pharmacy boards have issued emergency restrictions on how the drugs can be dispensed.

item.title: Coronavirus in China: Hubei Province Lockdown Eased After 2 Months
item.description: The province will let people outside Wuhan leave for the first time since late January. Despite the official sign of confidence, many fear the virus is still spreading silently.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: Workers with containers of disinfectant preparing on Tuesday to spray the central railway station in Wuhan, the city in Hubei Province that emerged in January as the epicenter of the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: A Medical Class ‘Minted by the Pandemic’
item.description: Across the nation, medical students are graduating directly into the path of an epic health crisis.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times
item.media:description: David Edelman, a fifth-year medical student at Columbia University, helped establish the Covid-19 Student Service Corps to support healthcare providers. “There’s so much to be done,” he said.

item.title: You’ve Got Mail. Will You Get the Coronavirus?
item.description: The practice of disinfecting mail dates back to the invention of quarantine. There’s little evidence it needs to be invoked today.
item.dc:creator: Nicola Twilley
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mail carrier in Manhattan on Monday.

item.title: How to See the World When You’re Stuck at Home
item.description: When you are quarantined or cancel your trip, you can still go on a journey. The secret? The author Reif Larsen says it’s Google Street View.
item.dc:creator: Reif Larsen

item.title: As Fleeing New Yorkers Are Told to Quarantine, Trump Says U.S. Should Reopen ‘by Easter’
item.description: Fleeing New Yorkers told to quarantine as Trump says the U.S. should reopen ‘by Easter.’
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

item.title: Coronavirus Patients in Limbo as Gilead Suspends Emergency Drug Access
item.description: The company says it will switch to a broader approach for its experimental drug, remdesivir. But it was overwhelmed by demand for a potential treatment promoted by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:description: Gilead Sciences headquarters in Foster City, Calif.

item.title: Medical Students, Sidelined for Now, Find New Ways to Fight Coronavirus
item.description: After medical schools ended contact with patients, disappointed students organized to collect masks, work at call centers and offer child care to health workers.
item.dc:creator: Penina Krieger and Abby Goodnough
item.media:description: Dustin Lamb, right, a student at the University of Colorado Medical School, accepted medical supplies during a public drive in Denver on Sunday.

item.title: Coronavirus Makes Daily Life Confounding. Here Are Some Answers.
item.description: Welcome to Dilemmas, where we find solutions to your toughest quandaries.
item.dc:creator: Jodi Kantor
item.media:description: Lise King is a Select Board member in Provincetown, Mass., where plane after plane has been arriving in the off-season.

item.title: These Doctors Have Specialties. Fighting Coronavirus Wasn’t One of Them.
item.description: The pandemic’s spread is creating new challenges for doctors who usually care primarily for patients with particular medical needs.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Johnathon Kelso for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Scott Isaacs, an endocrinologist in Atlanta, said he had been barraged with calls from his diabetes patients asking about how to get tested and treated for the coronavirus.

item.title: Thalidomide Use Did Happen Here, These Americans Say
item.description: They believe they were harmed in the thalidomide crisis of the 1950s and 1960s.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Audra Melton for The New York Times

item.title: The Story of Thalidomide in the U.S., Told Through Documents
item.description: A trove of archival records shows how in the early 1960s the Food and Drug Administration investigated the use of a drug that caused severe birth defects.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas

item.title: The Unseen Survivors of Thalidomide Want to Be Heard
item.description: The U.S. was supposed to have escaped the devastation of a drug that caused birth defects in babies overseas. This is the almost forgotten story of its toll in America.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Jenn Ackerman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Carolyn Farmer Sampson holding a photo of herself from when she was just a few months old in her home in Eagan, Minn.

item.title: 158 Million Americans Told to Stay Home, but Trump Pledges to Keep It Short
item.description: The White House warned of an alarming spread in New York City, but the president said “our country wasn’t built to be shut down.”

item.title: Scientists Identify 69 Drugs to Test Against the Coronavirus
item.description: Two dozen of the medicines are already under investigation. Also on the list: chloroquine, a drug used to treat malaria.
item.dc:creator: Carl Zimmer
item.media:description: A worker checking the production of chloroquine phosphate in China last month. There has been “anecdotal evidence” that chloroquine, a drug used to treat malaria, might work against the coronavirus.

item.title: What to Do if You or a Loved One Might Have the Coronavirus
item.description: A vast majority of those infected with the coronavirus will develop only mild to moderate symptoms. But many people remain frightened and wonder how and when to seek medical care.
item.dc:creator: Tara Parker-Pope
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Johnny Milano for The New York Times
item.media:description: A healthcare provider giving a coronavirus test at a drive-through in Jericho, N.Y., on Wednesday.

item.title: Daniel S. Greenberg, Science Journalist and Iconoclast, Dies at 88
item.description: He challenged peers who acted as “cheerleaders” for science, and influenced government science policy with a Washington-based newsletter.
item.dc:creator: Cornelia Dean

item.title: Warmer Weather May Slow, but Not Halt, Coronavirus
item.description: Nature may help diminish the pandemic if aggressive measures to control the spread of infections continue, experts say. That doesn’t mean the virus won’t return.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh and Ernesto Londoño
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Empty streets of Bogotá during mandatory isolation on Saturday.

item.title: As State Pleas Mount, Trump Outlines Some Federal Action; Senate Democrats Block Stimulus Package
item.description: New York State has 15,000 cases, roughly 5 percent of the pandemic’s growing global total. Senator Rand Paul tested positive for the coronavirus.
item.media:credit: Erin Scott for The New York Times
item.media:description: Senator Chuck Schumer speaking to reporters at the Capitol on Sunday.

item.title: The Hardest Questions Doctors May Face: Who Will Be Saved? Who Won’t?
item.description: As coronavirus infections explode in the U.S., hospitals could be forced to make harrowing choices if pushed to the brink. Planning is already underway.
item.dc:creator: Sheri Fink
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Laura Evans outside the University of Washington Medical Center in Seattle, where she is helping lead the response to the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: As Natural Disasters Strike, a New Fear: Relief Shelters May Spread Virus
item.description: The Red Cross has issued new guidelines for its shelters, screening people for symptoms and keeping bed six feet apart. That strategy will soon be tested.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle
item.media:credit: John Burgess/The Press Democrat, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Wildfire evacuees in California in October. The Red Cross now specifies that cots must be six feet apart.

item.title: Pences Test Negative; States Warn That Supplies Are Dwindling
item.description: Lawmakers negotiated a rescue package as recession fears loomed. One in four Americans is being asked to stay indoors.
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Donald J. Trump speaks during a coronavirus task force press briefing at the White House in Washington today.

item.title: How the Coronavirus Crisis May Hinder Efforts to Fight Wildfires
item.description: As many firefighters should be preparing for wildfire season, they are grappling with the fact that how they live and work could spread the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Kendra Pierre-Louis
item.media:credit: Jose Carlos Fajardo/San Jose Mercury News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A grass fire near Knightsen, Calif., in 2019.

item.title: Trump’s Embrace of Unproven Drugs to Treat Coronavirus Defies Science
item.description: Doctors and patients also worry that the president’s rosy outlook for the treatments will exacerbate shortages of old malaria drugs relied on by patients with lupus and other debilitating conditions.
item.dc:creator: Katie Thomas and Denise Grady
item.category: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
item.media:description: President Donald Trump and Dr. Anthony Fauci, right, the task force’s infectious disease expert, at a press briefing at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Coronavirus Test: What My Experience Was Like
item.description: Here are some of the experiences and bits of advice from those who have been able to get tested.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra E. Petri
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the National Guard at a testing site at Bergen County Community College in Paramus, N.J., on Friday.

item.title: As Coronavirus Looms, Mask Shortage Gives Rise to Promising Approach
item.description: Surgical masks are supposed to be used just once. But doctors in Nebraska are attempting a novel experiment as gear shortages arise.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Ultraviolet light is being used to decontaminate medical supplies at the University of Nebraska Medical Center in Omaha. Staff began using the first decontaminated gear on Thursday.

item.title: In Italy, Coronavirus Takes a Higher Toll on Men
item.description: Being male may be a risk factor for illness, just as being older is, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: Medical workers ushered in a patient to the newly-built Columbus Covid 2 wing of the Agostino Gemelli University Hospital in Rome this week.

item.title: A Different Way to Chart the Spread of Coronavirus
item.description: Those skyrocketing curves tell an alarming story. But logarithmic graphs can help reveal when the pandemic begins to slow.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang

item.title: What’s Happening to the Monarch Butterfly Population?
item.description: “Something’s going on in early spring,” a professor said, and researchers are trying to solve the mystery.
item.dc:creator: Karen Weintraub
item.media:description: Thousands of monarch butterflies gather in the eucalyptus trees at the Pismo State Beach Monarch Butterfly Grove.

item.title: Coronavirus May Keep California’s Nursing Students From Graduating
item.description: As many as 14,000 students may be unable to complete their rotations, making them unavailable to help.
item.dc:creator: Emma Goldberg
item.media:credit: Talia Herman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sharon Goldfarb, a nurse educator at the College of Marin in Kentfield, Calif. “We’re looking at 14,000 nursing students not graduating in the time of most dire need I’ve seen in my years as a professional nurse,” she said.

item.title: ‘None of Us Have a Fear of Corona’: The Faithful at an Outbreak’s Center
item.description: A gathering of 16,000 at a Malaysian mosque became the pandemic’s largest known vector in Southeast Asia, spreading the coronavirus to half a dozen countries.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.category: Shincheonji Church of Jesus the Temple of the Tabernacle of the Testimony
item.media:credit: Jes Aznar for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mosque in the Philippines run by Tablighi Jamaat, an Islamic missionary movement. A Tablighi Jamaat gathering in Malaysia has been linked to hundreds of coronavirus infections.

item.title: Young Adults Come to Grips With Coronavirus Health Risks
item.description: It can be a serious disease for younger people, and many millennials have chronic physical and mental health conditions.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times

item.title: Can't Get Tested for Covid-19? Maybe You're in the Wrong Country
item.description: Decisions and blunders made months ago have caused testing disparities worldwide. The science, it turns out, was the easy part.
item.dc:creator: Matt Apuzzo and Selam Gebrekidan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Afghan-Japan Communicable Disease Hospital in Kabul, Afghanistan. People returning from Iran had come in hopes of testing, but most were sent home and advised to self-isolate.

item.title: Smile? The Results From the 2020 World Happiness Report Are In
item.description: The Finns, known for downplaying their emotions, are the happiest people in the world. Do they have something to teach us about how to respond to the pandemic?
item.dc:creator: Maria Cramer
item.media:description: Revelers wore garlands of flowers to celebrate the summer solstice in Helsinki, Finland, in 2018.

item.title: Senate Debates $1 Trillion Rescue Plan; States Tell People to Stay Indoors
item.description: New Jersey, Connecticut and Illinois were preparing to issue restrictions like California and New York, and the U.S. was set to close its borders with Mexico and Canada.

item.title: Coronavirus Delays Work on NASA’s Moon Rocket and Capsule
item.description: Work will be suspended at two NASA centers, a setback that could end hopes for sending astronauts back to the moon in 2024.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: A component of NASA’s Space Launch System in January as it was being prepared for a move from the Michoud Assembly Facility in New Orleans to the Stennis Space Center in Mississippi.

item.title: With Minimal Evidence, Trump Asks F.D.A. to Study Malaria Drugs for Coronavirus
item.description: The use of the existing drugs against the new virus is unproven, and some shortages have already been reported.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady and Katie Thomas
item.media:credit: Feature China/Barcroft Media, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Production of the anti-malarial drug chloroquine last month at a factory in Nantong City in China.

item.title: Expect a Soggy U.S. Flood Season, but Less Severe Than Last Year’s
item.description: The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration expects major to moderate flooding for 23 states, but not as bad as last year’s ruinous spring.
item.dc:creator: John Schwartz
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Flooding in Hamburg, Iowa, in March 2019.

item.title: They Fled Coronavirus in Europe. Border Agents Asked if They’d Visited China or Iran.
item.description: Americans returning from Italy and Spain say border control officials didn’t screen them or tell them to isolate themselves.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: Milan Linate Airport on March 13. Some passengers arriving to the U.S. from Milan were only asked about travel in China, though the virus is spreading rapidly across Europe.

item.title: Climate Voters Still Want More From Biden
item.description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. keeps winning, and winning voters who say they care about climate change. But some of the most ardent climate activists still are not with him.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman
item.media:description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at a campaign event in New Hampshire in February.
